turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: At that point, basically, that has to be it.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: You're not going to tell me the rest?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Lemme talk to Buddy, set up a meeting.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Buddy?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Very nice...

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Yeah, I like it, I'm high up, I can see everything, you know? It's the Cadillac of minivans.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Compass.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Wow.  Mind if I take it for a spin?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Whatta you think, Chill?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: That's not bad. I think you got it down.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: I wouldn't think you're that dumb, leave over three hundred grand in the closet, underneath the extra blanket, but I guess you are.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: I didn't know where else to keep it.  Where would you?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: You're here a while, what's wrong with a bank?

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: They report it to the IRS.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: You don't open an account, Leo, you put it in a safe deposit box. Dip in whenever you want.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: You've been losing.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: I'm up twelve grand today.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: From when? You left Vegas with four- fifty?

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: Who told you that?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Now you're down to three-ten in the case. You must've cooled off quite a bit since you got here.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: How'd you know I was here?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Here's another tip...

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: It was Fay, wasn't it, told you about the money. She tell you my whole life history, for Christ's sake?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: I wouldn't let her if she tried. Why I'm here, Leo, basically, is to save your ass.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: How? By taking my money?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: You can keep what you won today. That's yours.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: It's all mine.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Sit down, Leo.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: You take all my money, but you're borrowing part of it?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: At eighteen percent, okay? And don't ask me no more fuckin' questions. I'm leaving.

turns.speaker: LEO
turns.text: But you won't know where I am. I don't even know where I'll be.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: I'll find you, Leo...

turns.speaker: MANAGER
turns.text: It's not one of these?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: You see a black leather jacket, fingertip length, like the one Pacino wore in Serpico? You don't, you owe me three seventy-nine.

turns.speaker: MANAGER
turns.text: Maybe you don't see my sign?

turns.speaker: MANAGER
turns.text: We call you a taxi.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Lemme get this straight. You aren't responsible for any lost articles like an expensive coat of mine, but you're gonna find Ray Bones' coat or get him a new one? Is that what you're telling me?

turns.speaker: MANAGER
turns.text: Mr. Barboni is a good customer.  Works for Jimmy Capp.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: I know who he works for. Where's your phone.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: The door from the patio, in back.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: You broke in?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: No, it was open. It wasn't locked.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: What if it was?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Well, basically, this guy owes a shylock fifteen thousand, plus he's a few weeks behind on the vig, the interest you have to pay.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: I know what a vig is.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: The interest is four hundred and fifty dollars a week on fifteen thousand?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: That's right. Three percent.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: But a week. That's a hundred and fifty percent a year.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: A hundred and fifty-six. Some'll charge you more'n that, go as high as six for five on a short-term loan. So three a week's not too bad.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: A real bargain.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: A couple days ago by, people from the airliner come to see his wife, tell her how sorry they are and all that their plane exploded and offer her a settlement, the amount based on what he would've earned operating the dry cleaner's the rest of his life. Leo had some kind of trouble with his kidneys, so they were giving him about ten years.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: How much is the wife offered?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Hey... Karen. How ya' doin'?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: What're you doing here?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: I wanted to come by, apologize for coming into your house like I did last night.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Lemme get this straight, you broke in again to apologize for breaking in before?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: No, no... you left the patio door open. You gotta stop doin' that, all the nice things you got around here.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Yeah, well make sure you lock it on the way out.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Rough day on the set?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: I spent all day crawling out of a grave. The costumer kept bitching 'cause I was ripping my nylons -

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Ripped nylons work. Makes the shot more real.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: ...That's what we finally decided.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Like in "Bride of the Mutant", when you played the whole end with that torn top.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: You saw that one?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Yeah. When you turn to the camera to tell the alien mother that her time on earth is finished... when you give us all that look, Joan Crawford wishes on her best day she had that much presence. Not even in "Mildred Pierce" - which by the way was a better book than a movie - did Crawford even touch the intensity you had in that look.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Yeah... that was a good scene. I mean, for a horror movie.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: For any movie.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: I know I'm better than what I've been doing the last ten years, walking around in a tank top and fuck-me pumps, waiting till it's time to scream.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Man, can you scream.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Yeah. It's a real gift.  I'm just saying it'd be nice, one time in my career to get the chance to say one great line. You know, like in that Bette Davis picture, "Cabin in the..."

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: "Cotton".

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Yeah, you know when Bette comes up to the guy on the porch, gives him a flirty look and says, 'I'd kiss you, but...'

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: How come you stopped making movies with Harry?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: I married Martin. That was a full- time job.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: You read Harry's new one? He says it's the best thing he's ever read.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: He must mean after "Slime Creature 3".

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: That why Harry came over last night? See if you could help him get Martin in his movie?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Harry's dreaming of a forty-million- dollar production he'll never get off the ground with a star he'll never sign. With or without my help.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Harry told me Martin loves it, he flipped.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Yeah, well Martin is known for his flipping. He flips over a script, and when the time comes to make a deal, he flips out.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Tell you what, I'll stop by Harry's office and pick up a copy for you.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Don't go out of your way.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Well, I gotta have a talk with Leo, my runaway dry cleaner.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Right. See how your story ends.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Yeah. Right.  Listen, "Touch of Evil"'s playing near my hotel. You wanna go check it out? Watch Charlton Heston play a Mexican?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: You been here the whole time?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: I just caught the end.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: I got you a copy of the script.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: I already read it. Harry left a copy at the house.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: What do you think?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: I think it's not horrible.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: I don't like the title. Or the main guy's name.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Then you've read it?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Not yet.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: You and Harry'll make a great team.  I'm gonna make a deal with him.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: There a part in it for you?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: I don't want to act in it, I want to produce it with Harry. Especially if I help him get Martin.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Sounds fair.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: What do you get out of it?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: That why you came over here, to ask me that?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: I want to know.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Why does anyone want to be in movies?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Yesterday, you were a loan shark.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: I was never much into it. All that bullshit having to do with respect. It's bad enough having to treat those guys like they're your heroes, having to smile when they make some stupid remark they think's real funny.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: And you think the movie business is any different?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Yeah well... I like movies. I figure if I help Harry make one, I'll find out what you have to do outside of have an idea and raise the money. That doesn't sound too hard. I was in the money business and I get ideas all the time.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: This thing's actually accurate. I bought it for ten bucks from a kid in a lawn chair on Sunset...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: You were supposed to wait for me with Harry at the restaurant.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Well actually, Martin the movie we came to talk about is Mr. Lovejoy.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Yeah. We understand you read the script and like it... a lot.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: A locker at the airport? Jesus Christ, Harry. Tell me you're not really that stupid.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: The guy's setting you up. You pulled out of their Freaks deal so he's paying you back.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: That was Martin. He wants to have lunch tomorrow. That is, if you can make it.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Depends, who pays?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Definitely not Martin. Movie stars never pick up the check. They have no idea what things cost. Most of them don't know their zip code and a lot don't even know their own phone number.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: How'd you meet Martin anyway?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Not unlike the way Nicki met him. Except it was a wrap party. Why?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: I don't know, I'm just havin' some trouble seeing you two together.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: You don't like Martin much, do you?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Oh, I like him. I just think he's... short. I mean, he's a good actor and all, but I'm wondering what it was exactly you saw in Marty.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: For starters, Marty wasn't Martin back then.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: So what about your story. You thought of a title yet?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: How 'bout Get Shorty? Except that isn't a movie. That's real life.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: How 'bout Chili's Hollywood Adventure.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: That's a different story. I'm still working on that one, you know, getting the visual fabric just right.  Although I've added to it.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Yeah. There's a girl in it now.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Really.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: I think you could be an actor. I know you're acting sometimes, but you don't show it.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: You thought I was faking?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: No. I don't mean that. I just meant in general.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: You don't mean a movie star? More like a character actor?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Whichever. Let's talk about it tomorrow.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: I mean I could see myself in movies Robert De Niro had been in. Or I could maybe do an Al Pacino movie, play a hard-on. But I couldn't see myself in ones, like say the one where the three guys get stuck with a baby. They don't know how to take care of it and you see these big grown-up assholes acting cute -

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Hey, Chili? Look at me.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Harry... My God...

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: What kinda food they serve at this Ivy place anyway?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Continental, but it doesn't matter. Martin won't order from the menu.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Because a movie star can never order straight from the menu. They have to think of something they have to have that isn't on the menu.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Harry, what're you doing? You're supposed to be in the hospital.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Yeah, Harry, you look like you belong in one of your horror movies.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: You sure?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: He's doing the same thing you did to him, playing Letterman on TV.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: It's not Dave. It's a movie.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Are you going down?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: You're as bad as Harry...

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: I'll go. I'll go.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: You okay?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Guy's got a fucking pink toilet, for Christ's sake.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Karen! What the fuck are you doing?!

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Oh, shit... I'm sorry... I thought that was... I'm so sorry...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Were you scared up there?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: You bet.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: You don't act like it?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: I was scared then, not now. How long you want me to be scared?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: I'll be right back.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Go get your stuff.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: What took you so long?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Couldn't find my toothbrush.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: They're closing the Granview. You know, theater down on Biscayne?

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Yeah, the guy owes Momo a few G's.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: What I'm thinkin' is maybe Momo could buy it.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Momo could buy it, I could run it for him. Show some Cagney films.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: What's Momo gonna want with an old place, shows old movies people don't care about no more. Outside of maybe turnin' it into a porno house, I don't think he's gonna give much of a fuck. And you already got a job.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: You sure it was Ray Bones took the coat?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: That's what the guy said.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Tomorrow, I see on the TV weather, it's gonna be nice and warm. You won't need the coat.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Hey, Chili.  Get your coat, but don't piss the guy off, okay? It could get complicated and we'd have to call Momo to straighten it out. Then Momo gets pissed for wasting his time and we don't need that.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Don't worry about it. I won't say any more than I have to, if that.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: No, I said I'm never goin' to bed. There's a difference. See, the article says most people die in their beds. I figure long as I stay outta bed, I'm safe.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: That's the dumbest thing I ever heard. Where do you sleep?

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: In an armchair. Or I go to a coffee shop, sleep there. Sit in a booth, pull my hat down.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: I told you not to -

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Don't say a fuckin' word.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: I hate to say I told you, but I did. I told you don't start nothing with him that time.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: You said don't say nothing and I didn't.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: No, you just broke his fuckin' nose instead.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: You gonna start that again? You're just like him, all you got room for in your brain is one fuckin' thing.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: All I know is he came by the barber shop, all fuckin' undone, wanting to know where you were staying in Vegas. I told him I don't know. I still don't.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: How'd he know I was in Vegas? You tell him?

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: He already knew it.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: Yeah, well, I'm in L.A. now.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Whatta you doing out there?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: I'm going into the movie business.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: What're you talking about? You wanna be a movie star?

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: I'm thinking about producing.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: How you gonna do that? You don't know shit about making movies.

turns.speaker: CHILI
turns.text: I don't think the producer has to do much, outside of maybe knowing a writer.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Hey, Chil? I think you're fulla shit.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Yeah, but whose point of view?

turns.speaker: DIRECTOR
turns.text: Whatta you mean, whose point of view; The audience's point of view.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Get down here. I wanna talk to you. Come on... right now...  She's gonna talk to Martin?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: All these camera moves and weird angles and shit are gonna distance us from the emotion of the scene.

turns.speaker: DIRECTOR
turns.text: What 'emotion'? Girl just got stabbed in the ear with an ice pick.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: She's scared! Fear is an emotion!  Look, kid, if you remember anything from your time working with Harry Zimm, let it be the three key words to filmmaking.

turns.speaker: DIRECTOR
turns.text: Yeah? What three words, Harry?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Pick 'n' Save.

turns.speaker: DIRECTOR
turns.text: Hm?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: You heard me, Pick 'n' Save.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: So Mildred says to the cashier, 'I saw the new Streisand picture.'  'God, I just love it at the end when she brushed Robert Redford's hair off his forehead the way she did when they were together, and the way they gave each other this look that said they still loved each other, but knew they couldn't be together. That look was so... romantic.'

turns.speaker: DIRECTOR
turns.text: That's great, Harry. So what's the --

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: What she did not say was, 'I just loved the way the director moved the camera so much it made me fuckin' seasick.' All she cared about was that look. All she remembered was that look. And why do we remember things in movies? Because we can see them.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Hello, Doris.

turns.speaker: DORIS
turns.text: Harry Zimm. You look like a wet kiss.

turns.speaker: DORIS
turns.text: Well, aren't you gonna offer me whatever it is you taste like?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Come on in.

turns.speaker: DORIS
turns.text: What a spectacular view.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Yeah, lovely. Last night I watched two guys carjack a Camaro down on the corner of Argyle there.  What do you want, Doris?

turns.speaker: DORIS
turns.text: I miss Murray, Harry.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Yeah, me too. He was a helluva good writer. And I would know. I discovered him. Made him what he was.

turns.speaker: DORIS
turns.text: What he was, was a hack, couldn't get a job writing for anybody but you.  I'm being honest. He was a lousy writer, but he was a good husband. I just didn't know it until too late.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I'm not sure how I feel about this, Doris.

turns.speaker: DORIS
turns.text: You seem to feel fine about it.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I mean morally. Murray was my friend.

turns.speaker: DORIS
turns.text: Murray's dead.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: So this means you've reconsidered our deal on Mr. Lovejoy?

turns.speaker: DORIS
turns.text: No. But now that you mention it, I did talk to a handsome executive at Paramount the other day... who just happened to get his hands on the script.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Yeah, what'd he have to say?

turns.speaker: DORIS
turns.text: He said if Martin's interested, I could get a half a million for it easy. But don't worry, Harry, I'm still giving you until Friday.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: How honorable of you.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: What's wrong?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Be quiet and listen.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I don't hear anything.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: When I came upstairs, you stayed to finish your drink. I told you to turn off the TV when you were through.  Come to think of it, I also told you you could sleep in the maid's room.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Yeah, well I turned off the set. I used the remote control thing and laid it on the floor. You know what could've happened? The dog came in and stepped on it, turned the TV back on.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: I don't have a dog.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: You don't? What happened to Muff?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Harry, are you going down, or you want me to?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Anyone skim the pool? It needs it.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Harry -

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I'm going.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: How did you get in the house?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: He's telling me an idea for a movie. It's not bad so far.  Sit down, have a drink.  Tell Karen, let's see what she thinks.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Maybe you didn't hear me.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: That Miami flight that went down, it was on the news every day for about a week. Harry must've been busy.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: That's where you got the idea?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: With your experience, you could always become an agent. Right, Harry?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Yeah, that's what we need. More agents.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Well. I got an audition tomorrow.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: No problem. You go on off to bed.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: What I'm saying, Harry, is I want you and your new buddy to get out of my house.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Oh, yeah, sure.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Harry, what're you still doing with those guys?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: He happens to be loaning me five hundred grand, no strings, I write any kind of agreement I want.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Harry, we spoke with Martin.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: 'We?'

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Chili and me.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Harry -

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Man's in town two days, thinks he's David O. fucking Selznick.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Which two?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Once their lives are in danger and you have the mob guy coming after them, it not only heightens the tension, it adds a wistful element to their love.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Mob guy?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I have to run. But what I hope to see, they begin to have misgivings about wanting the money. It becomes their moral dilemma and they try to rationalize keeping it, but in the end they can't. Can they?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: What money?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: The three hundred large. What other money is there?  I should keep quiet, I know, till I've read the script, but I've got a feeling about this one. I'm that shylock.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Shylock?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Karen. Wow. Look at you...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Hello, Martin.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I'm sitting here, I'm looking at you and I'm having these flashes. You know, flashbacks, of memories.  Of us.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Really.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Yeah and I'm wondering, how did it go wrong? How did it all... slip away?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: 'It' didn't slip away, Martin, you did... when you went off to fuck Nicki in the middle of my birthday party.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Oh, for Christ's sake -

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I know. I'm doing Shylock instead of a shylock. Okay, what's my motivation? The acquisition of money. To collect. Inflict pain if I have to.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Lufkin. His... agent.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Yeah, Karen knows him.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: But you are interested?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I'm intrigued, yeah. You know what might help you, take a look at the Cylone again, the way a visual fabric is maintained even while the metaphor plays on different levels. Hey -  This your ride, Chili?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Hi, sweetface. You look great. And mmmmm, you smell good, too.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I have to consider, I mean, as the mob guy, this is another man's wife I'm sleeping with.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: And after all, you have such morals.

turns.speaker: COASTGUARD DISPATCHER
turns.text: Arctic Warrior, Arctic Warrior, Arctic Warrior. This is United States Coastguard Station North Island. Over.

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: North Island, I wish to declare myself salvor-in-posession under section four two charlie of the International Maritime Convention.

turns.speaker: COASTGUARD DISPATCHER
turns.text: Affirmative, Arctic Warrior. What type of vessel?

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: A passenger liner. Over.

turns.speaker: COASTGUARD DISPATCHER
turns.text: Say again. Over.

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: A passenger liner, north island. Over.

turns.speaker: COASTGUARD DISPATCHER
turns.text: What is the vessel name, registry, and present position? Over.

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: Passenger vessel "Chimera." I will spell: charlie hotel india mary echo romeo alpha. No registry information is available at this time. I have determined to the best of my ability that the vessel has been abandoned on the high seas at position one seven four west, five seven north at...  Two zero one four hours zulu time. Over.

turns.speaker: COASTGUARD DISPATCHER
turns.text: Affirmative, Arctic Warrior. Please advise your salvage authority pending registry check. Over.

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: Roger, North Island. Arctic Warrior over and out.

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: North Island, please repeat? Over.

turns.speaker: COASTGUARD DISPATCHER
turns.text: Arctic Warrior, passenger vessel Chimera was lost at sea day two month two year one nine five three.  Over.

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: North Island, have you got any additional information? Over.

turns.speaker: COASTGUARD DISPATCHER
turns.text: Affirmative, Arctic Warrior. The vessel Chimera was registered to The Dobbins Kirk Line, Halifax.  Nova Scotia. Date of commission day nine month seven year one nine three two. Over.

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: Roger, North Island. I am tied to the passenger vessel Chimera. And she is afloat. Repeat, she is afloat. Over.

turns.speaker: COASTGUARD DISPATCHER
turns.text: Roger, Arctic Warrior. I say again, our records indicate the passenger vessel Chimera was lost at sea. Over.

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: Roger, North Island. Please advise pending further information. Over.

turns.speaker: COASTGUARD DISPATCHER
turns.text: Affirmative, Arctic Warrior. This is United States Coast Guard North Island Station. Over and out.

turns.speaker: COASTGUARD DISPATCHER
turns.text: Arctic Warrior, Arctic Warrior, Arctic Warrior. This is United States Coastguard Station North Island. Your radio check is affirmative. Over.

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: Roger that, North Island. Arctic Warrior whiskey alpha sierra bravo four zero niner two. Over and out.

turns.speaker: GREER
turns.text: Hear that, Dodge? Epps don't think it's a problem.

turns.speaker: DODGE
turns.text: I'll sleep good tonight knowing that.

turns.speaker: GREER
turns.text: Looks like Epps' gonna get some tonight.

turns.speaker: DODGE
turns.text: With that coxswain dickhead.

turns.speaker: GREER
turns.text: Hypothetically speaking, what if we get this boat to Sitka and find out somebody wants it back?

turns.speaker: DODGE
turns.text: They shoulda thought of that when they let her float away.

turns.speaker: GREER
turns.text: I don't care what, ain't nobody just gonna let us walk away with a ship that size.

turns.speaker: GREER
turns.text: You think the extra strain caused it?

turns.speaker: DODGE
turns.text: Nah. Everything was cool. It's just one of those things.

turns.speaker: DODGE
turns.text: How about now?

turns.speaker: GREER
turns.text: Sixty pounds.

turns.speaker: DODGE
turns.text: What? You sure?

turns.speaker: GREER
turns.text: That's what it says.

turns.speaker: DODGE
turns.text: Lemme see.

turns.speaker: GREER
turns.text: Are you crazy? Do you realize we got ourselves a ship? We own a ship, Dodge.

turns.speaker: DODGE
turns.text: Yeah, a ship that's supposed to have been lost at sea fifty years ago. You don't think that's just a little freaky?

turns.speaker: DODGE
turns.text: Fucker!

turns.speaker: GREER
turns.text: Take it easy, Dodge. It's only a piece of metal.

turns.speaker: DODGE
turns.text: Damn mind of it's own.

turns.speaker: GREER
turns.text: Morning, skipper.

turns.speaker: DODGE
turns.text: One minute I'm minding my own business, the next thing I know the whole place is burning up.  An oxygen tank must've blown on the welder. Started an oil fire.

turns.speaker: GREER
turns.text: Looks like it took out the backup genny too.

turns.speaker: DODGE
turns.text: What's so great about Sweden?

turns.speaker: GREER
turns.text: It's a beautiful country. Very clean. Very civilized. And cold.

turns.speaker: DODGE
turns.text: Yeah, but not as cold as those Swedish girls you only gonna dream about.

turns.speaker: GREER
turns.text: We'll see who's dreamin', m'man.

turns.speaker: DODGE
turns.text: Where's his boat, then? Where's his crew? He ain't gonna be out here by himself, that's for damn sure.

turns.speaker: GREER
turns.text: She's so big somebody could come alongside her on the other side and we'd never know it.

turns.speaker: DODGE
turns.text: Let's not be too hasty.

turns.speaker: GREER
turns.text: Yeah. Hell, what difference does it make if we report it now or later? We call this in now, gonna be Coastguard, FBI, who knows who, all over the place.

turns.speaker: DODGE
turns.text: I need lag bolts, especially one inch standard. And sheet metal. Preferably steel, about a sixteenth of an inch. Aluminium, even tin'll do.

turns.speaker: GREER
turns.text: I ain't no mechanic, just so you know.

turns.speaker: DODGE
turns.text: You find anything that even looks like a compressor. I don't care what, grab it.

turns.speaker: DODGE
turns.text: What day is it?

turns.speaker: GREER
turns.text: I don't know. Tuesday?

turns.speaker: DODGE
turns.text: Wrong. It's Friday.

turns.speaker: DODGE
turns.text: When they find out what it's carrying, they may not be so interested in what's legal.

turns.speaker: GREER
turns.text: Maybe you shoulda thought a that before you scuttled our boat.
